ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1-3 hours/week
2 hours
5hrs
If the reading is all done (and done on time) there is about 4-5 hours per week of work.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This could have been a insightful course but I felt it was very disorganized. The information is good but the course should have followed the layout of the text in order to be more cohesive.I felt that the chinese FDA lectures were not valuable. Maybe 1 would have been interesting but having the 4 or 5 that we had was a waste of time.

Very poor organization overall. There is clearly a lot to learn, and if we had stuck to the syllabus I think we would have learned a lot more. The fact that the syllabus was wrong about the topics we covered, the amount of homework we had and the projects we had to complete was very frustrating. Also, the tests did not really test anything we actually talked about in class.
class has a lot of potential, however, the syllabus was not really followed.

Course is very useful for understanding the whole drug approval process. I got to learn many more things about the FDA and clinical trials. For anyone who's intersted in working for pharma, I'd recommend this course.
Overall, it was a poorly organized course. The material became very repetitive after the midterm. Very few new topics were discussed during the second half of the course.

A lot of the lectures were repetitive, and there were far more homework assignments given than were listed in the syllabus. The course was very informative but did not follow the syllabus. It could be improved by updating the syllabus, since it is not an accurate description of the coursework.
Strengths:Great professor.Great book.Great new class for YSPH.Weakness:Should be a year-long course.
Interesting subject matter, but class was not well defined or organized. Guest speakers were excellent.

I think this was a good introductory course. I think that the book tends to be a little bit repetitive at times. The faculty might actually consider combining the course with the Clinical trials one and either making them 0.5 credits each (or even making it a 1.5 credit for the total year). There is a reasonable amount of overlap and the subject matter dovetails well (albeit there are certainly different goals of the study). I think that at time we could have gotten a bit more technical in terms of the "nitty gritty" of FDA and the regulatry world. It would have been good to hav done some case studies such as following a drug all the way from Preclinical regulation thru post-marketing issues.
The material is very practical, but not very well organized

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Robert Makuch  Hard to get an email response from. He seems to have a lot of good knowledge but is disorganized.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Clearly very knowledgable about the topic, but the lack of organization did not facilitate learning.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Great instructor, sensitive to students' needs. Really knows the materials and applies real-life examples. I enjoyed Dr. Makuch's class.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  He has a lot of knowledge about regulatory affairs, and his personal experiences were a valuable part of the class. He was very helpful to students and the guest lecturers he invited were very good.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Excellent instructor who had the great sense to invite the Regulatory Affairs class to many outstanding lectures that Yale sets up for the Chinese FDA.In addition, we had the best speaker ever in our class, PETER HUTT, ESQ.!!In- and out-of-classroom opportunities for learning pharmacovigilance and regulatory art and science ... spectacular!
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very approachable and friendly.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Prof Makuch is a solid, straightforward instructor. His expectations are clear and reasonable. He is very approachable and has good real-world experience which informs a lot of his instruction well.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: good.
Kyle is helpful and knowledgeable
Kyle was not very accessible, although it was clear that he was responsible for most of the structure of the course (which was much appreciated).
Good TA.
Bright, sharp, and engaged.Couldn't be better.
Difficult to contact and non-responsive at times.
Kyle did a good job. He graded the hw quickly and was certainly flexible when dealing with questions and issues.
Respond to email throughly

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If there was some reorganization (a lot of it, actually) and less of the Chinese FDA talks I would recommend it but not before that.
I would not recommend this course unless it is restructured.

Regulatory Affairs ... blending the art and science of epidemiology, biostatistics, and the law into a working framework for evaluating and managing risks and benefits in the realm of clinical health and progress.
RegAffairs was a good introduction for how FDA deals with product development.
useful to learn all those materials.
